Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will examine "tropical cyclone attribution" to identify the primary pre-existing disturbance(s) out of which each tropical cyclone in a season develops. The investigators will (i) develop and apply a means of attributing tropical cyclogenesis to one or more types of equatorial waves; (ii) address the wildly divergent views of existing papers in the literature on tropical cyclone pre-cursors; and (iii) attempt to merge traditional tropical meteorology practice with an alternative framework that makes use of equatorial wave theory. The goal of the last part of the work is to move some ideas from the research community into the operational tropical cyclone forecast community.

The investigators have examined the role of mixed Rossby-gravity, equatorial Rossby, easterly waves and the Madden-Julian Oscillation on tropical cyclogenesis in their previous NSF support. In this project they will study tropical cyclone formation within "monsoon gyres". These are broad subtropical low pressure areas that often produce multiple tropical cyclones. The ultimate goal of the two parts of this work is to develop a unified approach to understanding the precursor disturbances for tropical cyclones.

The broader impacts of this project include (i) the potential in merging operational forecast methods that rely on satellite images with some new theoretical approaches that better define the precursor disturbances, to ultimately improve the forecasts of hurricane formation on a time scale of 5-10 days, (ii) the training of graduate students and (iii) wide dissemination of results and findings in conferences, workshops, and the refereed literature. The principal investigator will also give talks on hurricanes to lay groups as part of outreach efforts.

NSF Grant ATM 0839991 Large-Scale Influences on Tropical Cyclones

 Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

 Although tropical cyclones are relatively small-scale features (order 100-300 miles), their formation is heavily influenced by much larger scale phenomena that are thousands of miles in diameter. This research addressed the role of these larger scale features, specifically equatorial waves, the monsoonal circulation, and “cyclonic gyres”. The gyres represent enormous low pressure areas that cover an area over subtropical oceans that exceeds the size of the contiguous 48 states in the U.S. In the first and third of these phenomena, operational forecasters rarely if ever consider their influence. As a result, we had two primary goals: understand the importance of equatorial waves, monsoons, and gyres on tropical cyclone formation worldwide, and describe how such influences work in order to educate forecasters on their relative importance.

 We have six publications on this research (see separate list). Each one provides part of the answer to the issues above. We note two papers here: Schreck’s paper on the global influence of five independent types of equatorial waves showed that these phenomena had differing effects in each ocean basin. They were most important in the northwest Pacific, where 85% of tropical cyclones formed under the influence of equatorial waves. They were least important in the Atlantic, yet still played a critical role in 50% of storms that developed. Figure 1 shows an example of this work for the western hemisphere. The shading shows the average magnitude of each equatorial wave type from 1998 to 2009, and the dots show the locations of tropical cyclones during that period that were strongly (red dots) or less strongly (green dots) influenced by the given wave type over the Atlantic and eastern Pacific Oceans. The paper gives numerous other examples.

 The second paper involves Molinari’s study on subtropical gyres. Almost no research has been done on these gyres. Our work is leading in multiple directions. We are interested in the global distribution of these gyres and their overall impact on the number of tropical cyclones and the amount of precipitation in the tropics. We have found they are strongly affected by the state of El Nino, and this will also be a future research direction.

 In addition to this work, three students (two PhD and one MS student) completed their degrees, made multiple presentations, and were authors or co-authors on multiple papers. Each learned to write and communicate their work, and each benefitted from numerous graduate courses on meteorology in our department. All three are now working full time at, respectively, the U.S. National Climatic Data Center, the Bureau of Meteorology in Australia, and the marine forecasting company AWT.
